plist.p: Please hold the line for the conference hosts to join the conference or a customer services representative.

Welcome to our 2011 results. As you can see on the first slide, our adjusted EBIT is up 2%, up to $5.4 billion. The Industrial assets have performed very well. They are up 18%, that's both as a benefit of the increased production from the asset base and from the higher commodity prices during 2011.

So Marketing is up 10%, that's excluding the Agricultural Products and we'll talk a bit about the Agricultural Products division performance later on. But if you take the Marketing business, even including the Agricultural Products division, it was a 35% return on equity. The Glencore net income is up 7%, up to $4.1 billion and we've had a strong operating cash flow of $3.5 billion. That's up 6% from 2010.

Robust balance sheet, we have $7 billion of committed liquidity available to the company and therefore, we're able to utilize this funding in 2012 to continue growing our business. And I'm sure a lot of people have read about commodity companies having shortage of liquidity and potential liquidity problems because of bank funding, and this clearly disproves that fact. We have $7 billion of committed liquidity available lines to us and therefore, this can be utilized for acquisitions plus for trading activities in the future.

Our growth projects are, overall, on track, on time and on budget. We do not have cost overruns on most of development projects, and they're very much going to be online for their projected expansions at the time they're all meant to be coming into operation.

Looking at our marketing activities, as I said earlier, the Metals and Minerals division, generally, the profit is – EBIT is $1.2 billion. That is 11% lower than 2010. Looking at this quarter in the division, you've got to remember on the copper zinc part of the business, there was massive restocking which took place in China in 2010. The same restocking did not take place in 2011. That's the reason volumes were slightly down and profits were lower.

We also were building up the Iron Ore division and therefore, during the phase of the building up and developing the growth in that side of the business, we were not making the same type of profits, the same per alloys was down slightly. But aluminum, the structure of the market allowed us to make higher margins and profits during the year and aluminum profit was up during 2011.

Looking at the Energy side of the business, as you are aware, the first half of 2011 was very strong towards the – the profits were up 55%, with an EBIT of $697 million and the reason is that on the oil side, as I said, the first half of 2011 was very strong (3:14) and was a very good year for oil. The coal part of the business was strong even though there's reduced volatility and lower freight rates, which resulted in less arbitrage opportunities. The pickup of agency business, the increase of various volumes around the world enabled the coal division to perform very strongly.
Agricultural business, as you can see, was a poor performing area of Glencore. The main reason, 2007 was an exceptional year. We made $659 million profit during 2010 and we made a (03:59).

Cotton caused a significant demand of these losses and we've explained the reasons during our mid-year results. The reason for these cotton losses, number one, is there's lesser volatility in the market of cotton during the year. The price rose from $0.85 a pound up to $2.50, came back down. And as we had fixed pricing contracts with our suppliers, we had a lot of nonperformance where the market rallied. And therefore, hedges that we had in place, we were not able to get the benefit on the physical side against those hedges. And therefore, we had to take a loss on the physical part of the business there.

Also, there was a disconnection between the futures market and the physical market. And during a particular period in 2011, the physical market was not following the same price mechanism as the futures market and that had an effect on the profit.

This was an unprecedented volatility in the cotton market. The cotton business was also a new business to the company. We brought in a bunch of individuals from outside of the business, which we don't normally do. We grow from within and we've rectified that first in the cotton market will now be priced on a quarterly-type basis and secondly, we've taken someone from the – a head or someone within the Grain division to head up that department and ensure it's run on the Glencore-type model.

Overall, on the industrial activities, as you can imagine, we have these large growth projects going forward and therefore, we increased production at Kazzinc where we have the Vasilkovskoye Gold production together with the zinc production; Katanga, the growth which we have in Katanga in the Congo, where we are growing that asset substantially; plus Mutanda. And as you can see, zinc is up 9%, copper here, production is up 35% and gold production, up 26%.

On the Energy side, it's well known, the expansion of our coal assets in Colombia, the Prodeco project. Prodeco has increased considerably, up 45% and we produced 14.6 million tonnes in 2011. The development of the port there is going very strongly. This will be developed by the end of 2012 and eventually, that project will get up to 21 million tonnes.

The good news on the oil side, the Energy side was the Aseng oil production in Block I in Equatorial Guinea came on stream earlier than expected and development there started in November 2011. We ramped up to 50,000 barrels per day. I think today it's getting closer to 60,000 barrels. And as you know, we own 25% of that investment and we will be developing the Alen field later on and that should add another 40,000 tonnes of production there.

In Agricultural, we're also growing that division on the industrial side of the business. Rio Vermelho, our sugar production, we intend to grow crushing capacity from 1 million tonnes to 2.7 million tonnes over there. And we've also bought four oilseed processing facilities and production of a new developed one in Argentina will come on stream, and that will add 3.6 million tonnes of processing capacity in that area of the business.

On the next slide, it's an important slide. If you look at Glencore compared to the other mining companies, our compound annual growth of these projects which are mentioned, Mopani, Equatorial Guinea, the E&P portfolio, Prodeco, Kazzinc, Katanga, Mutanda, we have lesser growth occurring in the next two years. Between 2011 and 2013, you will see we have a CAGR of 30.6% during those two years and, if you take it to 2015, we've got a 20% growth. I think this is a stronger growth than any of the mining companies and that shows the development of these projects and the quick ramp up regarding of these projects and most of them will be fully developed by the end of 2013.

Talking in detail about the production and the growth at these various assets. Kazzinc, as I said, the growth is occurring there very strongly on the zinc side. Not so strong on zinc, sorry, on the gold side, we went from 239 kt to 246 kt on the zinc side, and on the gold production from 326,000 that was Vasilkovskoye Gold to 390,000 tonnes. And in 2012, gold equivalents from this entire operation will grow to 800,000 ounces of gold production and we're pretty much on track over there at Kazzinc and Vasilkovskoye Gold.
We've also increased the reserves over there on the zinc side and there's been significant increase on the JORC reserves, which took place during 2011.

Katanga copper production went up. As you are aware, we are mining one of the highest grades of copper in the world, around about 4.5% cooper grade. We increased 57%, up to 91,000 tonnes at Katanga. During 2012, we expect to get to around about 140,000 tonnes of copper production. We've also developed the – we've increased the ramp-up to 310,000 tonnes and we're moving fast ahead on that. So therefore, at Katanga, we expect to get to around about 310,000 tonnes development by the end of 2013. So that is moving along nicely.

Mutanda, the other operation, we were well ahead of where we expected during 2011 and we increased production to 64,000 tonnes. We expect Mutanda to increase to 100,000 tonnes by – to produce 100,000 tonnes during 2012. And the intention is Mutanda, together with Kansuki, to increase their production to between 150,000 and 200,000 tonnes and more likely towards the top end of 200,000 tonnes.

If you look at our E&P portfolio in Equatorial Guinea, as I've said earlier, we developed that project earlier than expected, during November 2011. We kicked up to 50,000/60,000 barrels a day. And we expect to be at 60,000 barrels a day during 2012. The other subsea development there, the Alen field, we expect that in late second half 2013 to add another 40,000 barrels a day production. So, with these two fields, where we own approximately 25%, we should have about 100,000 barrels of oil today and with current oil prices, it's not hard to see how that will generate significant profits to the Group.

Prodeco, I mentioned earlier. Production increased to around about 14.6 million tonnes this year. The new port, which will allow us to load 21 million tonnes of coal through the new port, will be developed by the end of this year, early next year, 2013, and that will really give a massive expansion in that world-class operation.
And with that, I hand over to Steve to go through more of the financial details.
Okay. Thank you, Ivan, and good morning to everyone here in the audience physically and for those that are listening via the Web as well.

In terms of Glencore's financial performance, 2011 against 2010, I see today as somewhat of a non-event given these numbers will be released at the time of the announcement of the proposed merger with Xstrata on the 7th of February. So, you're all familiar with these numbers. There's absolutely no change whatsoever, both in numbers and geography and categories with what was reported back on 7th of February.

The actual preliminary results path of which you will all have a copy of what was released today, is very comprehensive, even more like an annual report type disclosure. We've given all the notes, all the reconciliations. So from a financial perspective, I think it's quite a lot to work through there. What I will try to do, in the next three or four slides, is to focus on one or two areas of additional color that may be useful in understanding our respective financial results.

So on Page 9, if we just look at some of the snapshots. Back up a slide, you've got it in front of you. The EBITDA, EBIT and net income numbers Ivan had alluded to those earlier on, where we did see improvements of 2%, 7% and 4% respectively, for those reasons, with notably the Industrial assets coming in slightly ahead of 2010 and the Marketing, largely due to the Agricultural underperformance against 2010, finishing slightly below 2010's level.

And in coming down to the Glencore net income level, income tax was obviously a relevant factor there, a few points on that. We had an effective tax rate, which has been applied and reported in respect to 2011 of 10%, which is a similar level to 2010's level. 2011 is somewhat of a transitional year for Glencore from a corporate tax perspective. For those that follow Glencore in years gone by, under the old partnership structure, we did have, from the corporate level, a layer for the employee profit participation shareholders, which was a feature of our structure in the past, used to get tax deductions at the corporate level which used to maintain low corporate tax.

Within that entity, that tax has nearly shifted up to the individual level. Now, that structure has collapsed as part of the restructuring and IPOing of Glencore back in May/June last year. We still had the benefit of six months of that, as well as the benefit of some other tax losses that were booked for the first time in 2011.

So the accounting tax rate, which still came in around the 10% level, going forward, no change to the guidance that we'd given last year at the time of the IPO, which is a Marketing accounting overall effective tax rate of around 10% and the Industrial side of the business, obviously depending on the jurisdiction which we're operating there, but circa 25% to a little below 30% is where it comes in.

So the future accounting tax charge is going to be the blend of the proportion that those two different income streams flow into Glencore. So the 10% is from an accounting perspective. You can certainly expect that to start trending more towards, if we assume 50/50 split, just as a mathematical split, you would have something approaching more the 20% rate from an accounting perspective.

However, from a cash perspective tax, it is important to recognize that we do have and you'll see it in the financial statements that we have, we've recognized there's $1.5 billion of tax-effective tax losses that this Group now has carried forward largely due to some tax deductions that were crystallized as a result of the IPO because as much as there was tax paid at the shareholder level, the corporate side, in collapsing those future obligations, did get various tax allowances and you can see we're talking about jurisdictions in Switzerland certainly. U.S. is another one where there were some tax deductions there going forward.

So $1.5 billion is the tax-effective and the gross amount is obviously much larger as well, which should provide quite a lot of near term cash benefits as the company is able to utilize some of those losses carried forward. So accounting-wise, we expect obviously an increase. Cash flow-wise, we would still expect to have a very low cash tax charge for the foreseeable future in the next few years at least.

I'll talk about net debt and some of those metrics for this slide later on. 2012, Ivan will talk a little bit on the outlook towards the end as well, but I think you can see a trend in Marketing. We have alerted that that stow well (16:27) across each segment. And on the Industrials side again, looking forward, we are expecting big growth in coal, be it Colombia, the oil, we'll have our first full year of production going forward in coal and, of course, copper and gold, we've got quite big expansions going forward.

If we look into Slide 10, really nothing much to add. It's just a geographical showing the Marketing performance, down 18%, really a function of the Agricultural year-on-year movement as well. Metals and Minerals, a largely consistent performance and good volumes and good premiums. Energy was the big increase, at least over 2010, particularly the oil market in the first half of 2011 which we spoke about last year, and some continued drag which is receding but there still is, there's some drag on the low wet freight market particularly in the oil side, which is both – we have some long exposure there which is a drag and in what that does to providing some arbitrage opportunity as well. And the Agricultural side, I think Ivan's covered it largely in the cotton side.

On the Industrial part of the business, if we look at the next slide, the year-on-year improvement was an 18% in the right direction, where again, you've seen growth across all segments, Metals and Minerals. You've seen some of the volume growth, which has flowed through to the bottom line. I'll provide some waterfall charts as well in the coming slides as well.

Offset, which we are not immune to, as anyone in this industry, and against a higher operating cost base, by virtue of not so much the general inflation environment which is quite low, but more the mining-specific inflation environment as we're operating in many jurisdictions where this industry continues to be a source of great activity or great expansion, competition for labor and access to power ties, diesel fuel, everything has created some sort of upward pressure on the cost side and we'll talk about how that affected Glencore going forward.

Own production, of course, much higher up in zinc, copper and gold as you can see. The Energy side is off a lower base but growing nicely, both on coal in Colombia. And a little bit of oil production, but that should really start seeing material benefits flowing through in early 2012.

And also the Agricultural Products business as we've invested quite a bit of capital the last 18 months through the sugar plants and various crushing facilities that Ivan mentioned too, particularly Argentina, Hungary, Poland, Ukraine to name but a few as well, where we've got some expansions.

If we look at Page 12, that waterfall chart, this is just looking at the Industrial side of the business, at the EBIT going from $2.9 million up to the $3.5 million in 2011. We're showing a price variance of $774 million positive and a volume variance of $272 million. To give you a split on the price variance, $523 million of that was Metals and $250 million was Energy, and that's very much gold and copper were the main contributors on the pricing on the Metals side.

And Prodeco, we've provided you the realized pricing for them on their export sales, which averaged $95 million against $82 million for year 2011 and 2010, which should still remain fairly robust down there given we have got 27 million of those tonnes have been sold forward at an average price of $94 million as well as the coal side.

As far as volume variances, $182 million of that $272 million has come from Metals and $89 million from the Energy. And again, you've seen the extra gold production, 26%, copper 35% and the extra coal production, 18%, making up the $89 million.

In terms of costs, you can see the negative $471 million variance. That's excluding FX, which is a smallish number by mining industry standards of $42 million. But the $471 million, if we relate that over our cost base for the year, that represents about a 5.7% increase in cost base, which if you do the numbers, I think across other peers and other competitors is respectable but it is – there are some things you can certainly control and many other things that are uncontrollable there in terms of power and diesel explosives and the like.

The currency appreciation only had an impact of $42 million for us. That was mostly coming from Australia at our Murrin Murrin operation, with the Aussie dollar gaining strength of around 12%, 2011 over 2012. There's been some further increases there, so I guess that could be a variance that would be seen certainly across many people operating within the Australian market space as there are other higher producing currencies as well. Extra depreciation, higher associate income, particularly coming from Xsrata and Mutanda, was also a – currently accounted for in the associate line given our 40% ownership.

If we move on to Slide 13, from a balance sheet and a funding perspective, shareholders' funds, of course, up to $29.3 billion, both from profit generation as well as the IPO net proceeds. In terms of net debt, $12.9 billion, only a reduction of around $2 billion or 12%; that's something that I'm sure many in this room will have expected to come down further, given also we were in June.

What we did to in the month of December and particularly seeing quite a big buildup in our working capital, and I'm speaking non-RMI working capital because mechanically when we do our calculations of net debt, we take off the – as part of coming to that $12.9 billion, we produced RMI of $13.8 billion, which is, in fact, slightly less than the prior year's $14.3 billion.

So most of that increase in current capital employed, which went up by $2.9 billion, was more in receivables than payables. $2.4 million of which was in the month of December alone and this was a particular period where I think the date of 31st of December was very relevant. Of course, it's the day of reckoning for many conference and financial institutions themselves, looking to improve positions, looking to many disclosures that they can around balance sheets. This was an opportunity for us to deploy some working capital either in adding receivables or even extending payable terms in some cases, but obviously doing it on attractive terms for Glencore.

So we did see certain what we would say is temporary in Asia, build up in working capital. There were some profitable funded opportunities. We would expect that to reverse over the course of first half 2012 in a stable commodity price environment which, of course, have seen oil also go up, as I said, in the first two months which, of course, is going to have some impact as well on our working capital.

Notwithstanding the increase in that sort of more temporary working capital, it does affect ratios and liquidity levels. The balance sheet and credit metrics continue to be strong for our particular rating category. FFO to net debt at 27% and the net debt to adjusted EBITDA at around the two level, as Ivan mentioned. Even with that build out in working capital, around $7 billion of committed liquidity headroom; that needs to be linked to some extent with what our refinancing obligations in the next 12, 18 months, two years, very little in fact.

Anything within our short-term area in current borrowings is mostly secured asset-backed facilities that by their nature tends to be 364, even uncommitted facilities, but they're funding receivables and inventory in borrowing-based structures that tend to be very straightforward in their extensions and renewal, it's more a question of what's the right margin on an annual basis. They tend to make up the biggest part of our current borrowing. And in our funding history, we've never had problem extending a refinancing. It's more a margin discussion that happens each year.

The ratings of the company, on a standalone basis just as Glencore, we've seen improvements back in the summer of last year both from S&P and Moody's. Moody's via a stabilization, S&P via the upgrade to the mid-BBB space.

Following the announcement of the Xstrata proposed combination back in 7th of February, both agencies have flagged potential upgrade potential for the new co, of which is the Glencore sort of surviving-type company structure, S&P via the watch positive and Moody's similarly via flagging upgrade potential.

Risk, the VaR, as I've measured it, we do report and there's more details of it in the preliminary report and the annual report itself in a few weeks. We'll talk to that more as well as being fairly modest at the 39% level or at the very – 0.1% fraction of our shareholders' equity.
So with that, I'll hand over back to Ivan.

Okay. Thanks, Steve. Just giving an idea of where we see things for the balance of the year 2012 and going forward. If I look at the Marketing business and we look at the Marketing business separately, production, as you know, we're getting this massive production at most of our assets. As we get this increased production from our own assets, we are able to increase our activities on the Marketing side on our third-party tonnages. It gives us advantages to do more price arbitrage, utilizing our own tonnes, together with third-party tonnes. It also allows us to do more blending, bigger blending opportunities, switching opportunities on the concentrate side of the business between smelters and the mines. And therefore, we've always noted as we increase the production at our own assets, we increase our third-party marketing. So that allows us to increase our volumes.

Also, another sign is the weakness we saw during fourth quarter 2011, has turned around during first quarter 2012. And we've already seen the recovery take place on a lot of our activities, bigger volumes are occurring during the first two months of the year. And in most of our – all our commodities in fact, the Marketing activities have increased in the first two months and the profits are looking very strong during that period.

On Industrial side of the business, as I mentioned earlier, that we do have these big ramp-up operations. At Katanga, we will be taking Katanga to 310,000 tonnes, which we envisage to be completed by the end of 2013. Mutanda, we will ramp up to 200,000 tonnes and we're going to get the full year's production from there. And then Aseng field in 2012, as I said earlier, the 60,000 barrels a day, our 25% of that and on the Alen field, towards the latter end of 2013, which will add another 40,000 tonnes.

We also, as you know, acquired the Optimum Koornfontein, Umcebo operations in South Africa. That is going to give us a massive resource base in South Africa and you will see us increasing our production from those South African reserves, which will add a lot to the Energy/Coal division.

So, overall, we see the underlying economic fundamentals showing signs of improvement during 2012. As I said, the strength of our own organic growth, demand across the world for these type products, the commodity market looking stronger during this year, once again, we do see the difficulties of the increasing production around the world. You do see the developing countries, the grades decreasing. You see the grades of copper in Chile decreasing. You see production amongst many of the producers decreasing, whilst we are increasing our production in these areas, such as the Congo, Colombia and Kazakhstan.

As Steve mentioned earlier and I mentioned earlier, a lot of people have asked about the balance sheet. We do have this robust balance sheet. We do have $7 billion of committed line. This is very important going forward. People have heard about – we talk about the banking lines tightening up for commodity companies, the smaller commodity companies are seeing tightening of their trade lines. We are not experiencing any of that. As you know, we have our revolver where we have 90 banks supporting us under a one and three-year revolver. That is fully funded and that allows us to take advantage of this liquidity, to have these better trading opportunity, which the smaller companies are finding difficulties to obtain.

We have the proposed merger with Xstrata. And as we've always said and I've said during our previous discussions, we believe putting these two companies together adds value for the shareholders. The flow of the Xstrata commodity into the Glencore system will add value for both shareholders. We've indicated what the synergies will be on that. That will create net royalties to both shareholders. And we believe we will then have a unique model, which no one else has in the mining industry.

It's diverse. It's fully integrated. It ensures we get the full value of the product along the value chain from production to the mine, to delivery, to the end customer via storage benefits, blending benefits, being able to arbitrage the price differentials.

As you well know today, the world is changing. We are producing commodities in more difficult areas of the world. We are selling commodities in new areas of the world. Glencore has been active in all these areas for many years. We have offices in all these countries. We have 54 offices around the world.

So we add a new dimension to Xstrata. And together, I believe we'll be a unique company with great assets, both long-term assets, producing for the long-term, Glencore bringing quick ramp-up projects to this model. Our projects ramp up very quickly as you've heard earlier today. And together with the Marketing activities, the diversification of having the marketing together with the production, it will be a unique model which will take us well forward for the future.
I think that's it. We're open for questions.
Thank you. So with that intro, (31:24) several questions (31:25) go to the phones. Who's got the microphone? Okay. Who's going to ask one first? It's Ash down there at the front.

Hi. Thanks, gentlemen. Ash Lazenby from Liberum Capital. Just a couple of questions if I may. First of all, I realize it's still very much in the early stages of negotiation, but in terms of the Kansuki and Mutanda tie-up, would you have any indication as to when we might hear something there and also with the buying out of some of those minorities?

And then secondly, looking really beyond 2015 in terms of your assets, I guess particularly probably within the copper within Africa, where do you see most potential across those assets in terms of expandability beyond the 2015? And obviously, as you talk about, with the quick ramp up of projects, what we might be able to see there kind of on a blue-sky potential?
Telis, do you want to handle that? We're staying on Mutanda-Kansuki and those questions?

Sure. As we've mentioned previously, we are in negotiations to merge Mutanda and Kansuki and end up in a situation where we will have the majority of both of those entity. That is ongoing. And we expect to announce something fairly shortly, within a matter of months.

As far as potentials and forwards, we think that Mutanda-Kasuki is something that exceeded our expectations in term of possibilities for us to ramp up. It's almost brand new, kind of like greens and brownfields with no legacy. It's very high grade, 4.5%, same as Katanga, but without any legacy.

We will reach 110,000 tonnes of cathode in production by June this year and 15,000 tonnes of coal. We will go for sure to allow another 50,000 tonnes of SX/EW. This will be to the merged entity. It will take us to 150,000 and then the question is do we develop a sulphide ore body that is very shallow underground, like 200 meters, again, high-grade sulphide ore body, put a concentrate there that will produce 100,000 tonnes (33:56) copper and ship that from Mopani. Now, before we can – we can increase the 210,000 tonnes of cathodes and add the sulphides as well. So, we are currently, basically doing the feasibility study and we're seeing what is the best course of action there.

The Katanga side, that's pretty well flagged. What we've done, as Ivan mentioned before, is we have accelerated what we call the Phase IV, which is a $650 million investment on a 200,000 tonne SX/EW which will be brand new and that will take the production up to 210,000 tonnes.

What we intend to do is we'll then scale down the current production in (34:41) which we think will be running at around 140,000 tonnes of metal, takes that down to 110,000 on a (34:51) basis because of the refurbishment that needs be done and run Katanga at 210,000 and that we think will be the maximum that we think Katanga should be.
With the continued (35:03) we're not sure of the war in the country. The question is, how do we best want to work to ramp up within the content of the infrastructure which is very power (35:17).

Certainly, the key to growing in the Congo, as Steven said, we've got sufficient ore, it's just a matter of how do we handle the power situation, roads, transport, et cetera. Now, if we can develop the rail lines or do something on the rail lines, taking it to – we're thinking of taking it to Darussalam now, and if we can get that sorted out, that (35:37) effect. So that it all depends how you develop the infrastructure in those countries.

Now, your question where do we go from – where else are we going? We've got the growth. We've highlighted the growth we have in the Congo. We've highlighted the growth in Colombia, et cetera. But remember, as much as people look at Glencore and I've heard about it when we're talking today about the Xstrata merger, you hear about the long life projects. We do have long life projects. Many of our (36:01) projects are 40, 50-year life projects. Kazakhstan, the gold operation is a long life project.

You've also got to remember, where we are in Kazakhstan, there's a lot of other gold reserves around there which can be developed and fed through our infrastructure, where there's full smelting refining capacity there. We have spare capacity. So we can develop other reserves around that area and we're always looking for other reserves. It's no secret. There are other reserves, which can be bought, owned by other parties when it doesn't make sense for them to build a full smelting refining facility there because it's not economical.

For us to do it, to just develop those reserves and put it through our smelter refinery is pretty easy. So it would not be surprising to see us grow our coal production in Kazakhstan substantially by adding on other reserves there.

You've also got to remember our reserves and what we've purchased, as I mentioned earlier, in South Africa, on the coal side in South Africa, we have massive resources, yeah. I think we have correspondingly we have 2.5 billion tonnes of resources together with all our projects for the (37:10) Koornfontein, and Optimum in South Africa and that allows us to really grow our production in South Africa, I know which is very constrained, but which is where the rail lines can increase and as it does increase, we can increase our production over there.

You also got to remember in South Africa, there's also shortage of coal for Eskom power stations. And with the new power stations coming on stream, Eskom is trying to tie up supply of coals substantially on a long-term basis. We are able to increase our production considerably over there.

If you look at our West African oil development, as you are aware, we've got these developments in both Alen and Aseng fields. We also got the Carla and Diega developed preserves in the Alen and Aseng fields, and that should kick in production from 2015.

We also have developments where we're drilling in Cameroon so we've got further potential development there. And together with the infrastructure that we have there, where the FPSO, which we can move around in that area and go to other areas as we develop the Carla and the Diega fields, you could see both increases of production in that area from 2015.

Also, you people, where you're also not focusing on is you've got to remember we also own RussNeft in Russia. As you are aware, RussNeft produces around about 280,000 barrels of oil a day. That is reserves which it can grow. We are showing our shareholding in that. We are not showing a value on that shareholding in the coming – we have the $2 billion loan to RussNeft, which is being serviced. But RussNeft does a big – it can expand and even just maintaining at 280,000 barrels of oil and keeping that for the long term, it does have sufficient reserves where that can maintain it for the long term. That is for the expansions of the company.

So on the relevant assets and other reserves, we have our bigger expansions from 2015. The good thing about these expansions, a lot of them are brownfields. What Glencore is focusing on here and we always have is return on equity. As you know, this company has always managed a return on equity over the 37 years we've been around, but if we look at the past 20 years, between 35% to 60% return on equity.

So on any assets we are developing and any of these growth assets, it's purely going to be based upon a return on equity, remembering most of us working in this company have a fairly big stake in the company. So we're very much guided by return on equity. We are not building projects for the fact of building project. I'm not saying greenfields are not good projects, but greenfield projects we've seen in the past, we've experienced it ourselves at Manala (40:00), tend to have cost overruns of more difficult projects.

We like to focus on easier projects, projects we understand, can be developed at a quicker rate with less risk, with less chance of capital overruns.
